channel.title: NYT > U.S. > Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: House Republicans Accuse D.C. Police of Manipulating Crime Statistics
item.description: The committee cited interviews with police commanders in an effort to buttress President Trump’s federal takeover of law enforcement and the National Guard deployment in the capital city.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The committee said interviews with the city police’s seven district commanders showed the department’s leadership had put an aggressive emphasis on lowering crime numbers.

item.title: Inside the Clintons’ Fight to Avoid Testifying in the House Epstein Inquiry
item.description: Bill and Hillary Clinton have repeatedly offered to provide sworn statements, but Representative James R. Comer has threatened to hold them in contempt of Congress if they fail to appear.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: For months, the Clintons have been engaging with Mr. Comer far more than was previously known to respond to his requests and avoid having to appear on Capitol Hill.

item.title: The War on ‘Wokeness’ Comes to the U.S. Mint
item.description: The Treasury Department unveiled new coins celebrating America’s 250th anniversary. They failed to include planned designs featuring abolition, women’s suffrage and the civil rights movement.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry and Rachel Wisniewski
item.media:description: Actors surrounded Brandon Beach, the U.S. treasurer, and Kristie McNally, the Mint’s acting secretary, at a coin unveiling this month at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia.

item.title: How The Times Analyzed the S.E.C.’s Cryptocurrency Enforcement
item.description: The New York Times set out to understand — and quantify — just how much things had changed within the agency after President Trump resumed office.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Fuller, Ben Protess, Sharon LaFraniere, Seamus Hughes, Julie Tate and Alex Klavens
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait array in the lobby of the Securities and Exchange Commission showing President Trump and Vice President JD Vance; its chairman, Paul S. Atkins; and Commissioners Hester M. Peirce, Caroline A. Crenshaw and Mark T. Uyeda.

item.title: The S.E.C. Was Tough on Crypto. It Pulled Back After Trump Returned to Office.
item.description: An investigation by The Times found the administration’s change in enforcement benefited the industry, including companies that had ties to the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Andrea Fuller, Sharon LaFraniere, Seamus Hughes and Elena Shao

item.title: The Army Made a Blind Black Soldier a Surrogate for Robert E. Lee
item.description: For more than a century, this Black soldier from Virginia was remembered by nearly no one. Then this year, someone at the Pentagon found a use for him.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: National Museum of African American History and Culture
item.media:description: Pvt. Fitz Lee in 1899, with his Medal of Honor on his jacket.

item.title: Appeals Court Says Trump Must End Los Angeles Deployment by Monday
item.description: While the decision did not remove the National Guard troops from the president’s control, it blocked him from using them in the nation’s second-largest city.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump deployed about 4,000 California National Guard troops to Los Angeles in June.

item.title: University of Maryland President Cleared of Plagiarism
item.description: The claims last year by a conservative publication against Darryll J. Pines prompted a yearlong investigation and an extensive review of his published works.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Darryll J. Pines, the University of Maryland’s president, has been cleared of plagiarism allegations.

item.title: Reader Mailbag: A Pause on Gerrymanders, and a Risk in Primaries
item.description: Indiana Republicans reject redrawn maps, and battle lines have been drawn among Democrats in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:description: Jasmine Crockett entered the Texas Senate race.

item.title: ‘The Interview’: 3 Senators Who Quit On Why Congress Won’t Stand Up To Trump
item.description: The current and former lawmakers get candid about bipartisan politics, party leadership and the state of the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Garcia-Navarro
item.media:credit: Philip Montgomery for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Manchin, Tina Smith and Jeff Flake.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Pardon’ of Tina Peters Rejected by Colorado Officials
item.description: The president’s stated intention to pardon Tina Peters, jailed for tampering with election machines in 2020, has set off a legal fight over the extent of Mr. Trump’s pardon powers.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Larry Robinson/The Grand Junction Daily Sentinel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former Mesa County Clerk and Recorder Tina Peters, middle, during her sentencing for her election interference case at the Mesa County District Court in Grand Junction, Colo., last year.

item.title: Biden Has Raised Little of What He Needs to Build a Presidential Library
item.description: His library foundation has told the I.R.S. that by the end of 2027 it expects to bring in just $11.3 million — not nearly enough for a traditional presidential library.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold, Shane Goldmacher, Tyler Pager and Theodore Schleifer
item.category: Biden, Joseph R Jr, Presidential Library and Museum
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has only just begun to raise money for a presidential library, starting with an event for potential donors on Monday in Washington.

item.title: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Fee Faces Lawsuit
item.description: California and New York are among the states arguing that the Trump administration’s decision to charge that fee for skilled foreign workers is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump after signing a proclamation instituting the visa fee for some foreign workers in September.

item.title: Judge’s Order Complicates Justice Dept. Plans to Again Charge Comey
item.description: Justice Department officials have been considering whether to bring new charges against James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, after a different judge dismissed the original case against him.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Monica Jorge for The New York Times
item.media:description: A judge’s order suggested that sloppiness by the Justice Department had helped to sabotage President Trump’s demands to use the criminal justice system to go after James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director.

item.title: Government Can Withhold Funds From Planned Parenthood, Appeals Court Rules
item.description: A three-judge panel threw out a lower court’s order, allowing the Trump administration to continue defunding the group and other major abortion providers.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Planned Parenthood has said that if allowed to take effect, the provision could lead to closures of the organization’s health clinics and decimate its budget.

item.title: U.S. Boarded Ship and Seized Cargo Heading to Iran From China
item.description: The seizure last month came amid fears of a renewed conflict between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Yantian port in Shenzhen, China. The United States had been tracking cargo as it made its way from China to Iran.

item.title: House G.O.P. Releases Health Plan That Would Allow Subsidies to End
item.description: The legislation, expected to come to a vote next week, would make changes that could eventually affect health care costs but are unlikely to immediately curb rising premiums.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: To Get to Oslo, Machado Skirted Military Checkpoints and Survived Rough Seas
item.description: An American firm with experience in special operations spirited María Corina Machado, the recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, out of the country in a secretive land, sea and air operation.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero
item.media:description: María Corina Machado spent the last year hiding from President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela’s regime.

item.title: U.S. Lifts Sanctions Against Justice Alexandre de Moraes of Brazil
item.description: A senior Trump administration official said that maintaining sanctions against Justice Alexandre de Moraes was no longer in the interest of the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Alexandre de Moraes reading the charges against former President Jair Bolsonaro during the opening session of the trial in Brazil in September.

item.title: Trump Faces Same Demons as Biden: Age, Health and the Economy
item.description: Too old? Tough economy? The presidents change, but the troubles are familiar.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:description: President Trump has recently faced questions about his health and handling of the economy.
